item.title: Chicago Allows Summer Curfews for Minors as Mayor Vows Veto
item.description: Chicago’s city council voted to give its police chief the green light to enforce temporary curfews for minors in a bid to curb violence that has typically ramped up during the summer months, prompting Mayor Brandon Johnson to vow to block the measure.
item.dc:creator: Miranda Davis

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk along the Concrete Beach in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024. Chicago is delaying its $643 million bond sale that was expected to price last week amid volatility in the $4 trillion market for state and local bonds.

item.title: New Zealand Pauses Cook Islands Funding Over China Agreements
item.description: New Zealand has paused funding to the Cook Islands after the tiny South Pacific nation signed agreements with China without the expected level of consultation.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

item.title: Trump Wraps Situation Room Meeting as Iran Plan Remains Mystery
item.description: President Donald Trump concluded a meeting Wednesday with top advisers as he weighed whether to plunge the US into the ongoing war between Israel and Iran, but the White House offered few clues about whether he had decided to join the offensive aimed at destroying Tehran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Jordan Fabian

item.title: Pakistan Army Chief Discusses Israel-Iran Conflict With Trump
item.description: President Donald Trump met Pakistan’s army chief Wednesday in Washington as the US considers supporting Israeli airstrikes on Iran, a country with a cooperative and complex relationship with the government in Islamabad.

item.title: Colombian High Court Blocks Petro’s Referendum on Labor Rights
item.description: One of Colombia’s highest courts blocked President Gustavo Petro’s proposal to hold a referendum on boosting labor rights.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Petro, Colombia’s president, speaks during a rally at Bolivar Square in Bogota, Colombia, on Thursday, May 1, 2025. Petro presented a bill on Thursday that seeks to submit proposals for labor rights and working conditions to a public referendum after Congress rejected his labor reform earlier this year.

item.title: Trump Tells Supreme Court No Need to Rush to Consider Tariffs
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration urged the US Supreme Court to turn away a request for fast-track review of his sweeping tariffs, saying the justices should give lower courts more time to weigh in.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump holds a reciprocal tariffs poster during a tariff announcement in the Rose Garden of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 2, 2025. Trump is imposing tariffs on US trading partners worldwide, his biggest assault yet on a global economic system he has long bemoaned as unfair.

item.title: US Orders Social Media Vetting for Student Visa Applicants
item.description: The US State Department has ordered a review of student visa applicants’ social media presence and told them to make their profiles public, stepping up measures to restrict foreign nationals’ entry to American campuses over national security concerns.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Unrecognizable male student text messaging on mobile phone while being on a break in the classroom.

item.title: Senate Republicans Float Rural Hospital Fund to Ease Impasse Over Tax Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans are crafting provisions to provide funding for struggling rural hospitals in order to resolve an impasse on Medicaid changes that is one issue holding up passage of President Donald Trump’s tax-cut bill.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Erin Durkin, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: A trucks drives towards a sign pointing to the emergency room entrance at OSF Saint Paul Medical Center in Mendota, Illinois, U.S., on Tuesday, April 14, 2020. Hospitals are facing shortages of masks, gowns, gloves, tests, ventilators, cleaning supplies and toilet paper, a federal survey of hospital administrators conducted in late March found.

item.title: Social Security Warns of 23% Benefit Cut by 2034 Without a Fix
item.description: The Social Security trust fund will become unable to pay scheduled benefits to retirees and the disabled as soon as 2034, new projections show — one year earlier than last year’s estimates.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte, Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: The US Social Security Administration headquarters in Woodlawn, Maryland.

item.title: Trump’s Iran War Talk Testing His Ties With MAGA Loyalists
item.description: Donald Trump’s hints that he may dispatch the US military to help Israel destroy Iran’s nuclear program has spurred a revolt from his typically faithful America First base, further dividing a party already struggling to unite around the president’s second-term agenda.
item.dc:creator: Mario Parker, Jamie Tarabay, Nancy Cook

item.title: Czech Government Wins Confidence Vote Months Ahead of Election
item.description: The Czech government survived a confidence vote initiated by the opposition over a Bitcoin scandal, shouldering through the turmoil ahead of a parliamentary election scheduled for October.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Dudik

media:content.media:description: Petr Fiala, Czech Republic's prime minister, during an interview at the parliament in Prague, Czech Republic, on Friday, Dec. 6, 2024. Fiala, whose government has been among the most vocal in NATO in denouncing the Kremlin’s invasion of Ukraine, said forcing Kyiv to cede territory will only encourage Vladimir Putin’s war machine.

item.title: Trump Again Pushes TikTok Sale Deadline With 90-Day Reprieve
item.description: President Donald Trump plans to extend for a third time the deadline for Chinese company ByteDance Ltd. to divest the American operations of TikTok, allowing the social media app to keep running in the US while negotiations proceed.
